content: @WG-async-foundations :wave:
So in terms of classic issue triage there's not really anything to talk about today :)
I'd like to open it up for announcements
and then I suspect @nikomatsakis wants to talk about the vision doc some?
I do :)
I'm trying to decide if I have any announcements
I guess an announcement is that we have a draft vision doc blog post available; still some active debate about when to publish (that's something we could talk about)
https://github.com/rust-lang/blog.rust-lang.org/pull/793
shall we discussion vision doc some more then? :)

nikomatsakis said:

I guess an announcement is that we have a draft vision doc blog post available; still some active debate about when to publish (that's something we could talk about)

Do we make that decision or is it the core team?

Depends I guess on where it gets posted. The main rust blog is typically core team. The Inside Rust blog is typically more the domain of the teams themselves. But I think we should talk about what we want.
My main concern is that I don't want to delay very far, because we could spend all year crafting the perfect doc
There are a few tweaks I might like to make
I don't have strong feelings either way tbh, but if we publish it today it shouldn't be too late
but at the end of the day, i think we're in the "diminishing returns" phase
Initially I hoped to get it out wed or thu, but that proved too hard
if we post it today, we can ask people to write stories within a week, and that seems...tight but not that unreasonable, esp. if we will read them afterwards
let's look over the overall schedule
I'll show you what I had in mind :)
yeah as long as there is a weekend in that window

• 2021-03-01 -- 2021-03-06 <-- we are now at the end of this week
  • 2021-03-08 -- 2021-03-12 <-- open call for blog posts, we are drafting concurrently
  • 2021-03-15 -- 2021-03-19 <-- I think we should have PRs open with stories this week
  • 2021-03-22 -- 2021-03-26 <-- iterate here, taking further blog posts into account
  • 2021-03-29 -- 2021-04-02 <-- I'd like to be "first draft of status quo stories" by end of month
that's the high-level summary :)
it sounds like the first draft is only the status quo (and maybe tenets), correct?
that is my plan
sorry
let me rephrase that
there, updated again :)
that said, one thing I want to do is to brainstorm a bit the characters
not so much who they should be (yet)
but to talk about the axes of users we are looking to represent, and the range of values on those axes
example:

• possible axes
    - Programming languages you know and love
    - Dynamic languages (node.js, browser, python, Ruby)
    - C++
    - Java, Kotlin
    - Sync Rust
    - Experience with Async programming
    - What are you building
    - WebApp
    - Server
    - Protocol library
    - Embedded
ack
let me move that to a hackmd
here
yes, I like that idea
I think this is a useful structure (hat tip to @Yoshua Wuyts, we came up with it together while brainstorming)
if we could flesh taht out a bit, we can also describe the characters in terms of those axes
we obviously can't cover every combination, but I am concerned that folks don't always see themselves in the characters as is
four stories aren't going to cover the full range of backgrounds so it's nice if we can refer back to this
so
I don't think there are four stories
I think there are lots of stories
but I'd like to have 4 characters
who are in those stories :)
I suspect we can cover every story with a "best representative" character, and then have the FAQ say things like "does this apply to other characters?"

if there is some narrow story that really doesn't fit our characters, either we add a new one, or else maybe for that particular story we write it in a different way? I'd be curious if that will happen
I'm curious whether folks in this meeting see missing axes in the list above
@Esteban Küber or @Sean McArthur are you around?
I know you both had thoughts about ranges of users

nikomatsakis said:

I suspect we can cover every story with a "best representative" character, and then have the FAQ say things like "does this apply to other characters?"

does this make sense, @tmandry ?
yep
I'm really wanting to have a "character sheet" for each character
showing their answers to these questions:)
so, we can always add to the "what are you building" section :)
yes! what is missing
I mean obviously it's not complete
high performance server probably has a lot of sub-categories for instance
do they matter?
the question for us to ask is:
does it meaningfully change the experience for the purpose of some story
it'd be ok to list out some of them in parenthetical, if not, just to show we know
it's hard to say for some of them
I guess we can start with more rather than less
and coallesce
like I said yesterday, I'd like to see a nod toward async I/O
and I think HPC has some interesting applications

tmandry said:

like I said yesterday, I'd like to see a nod toward async I/O

I don't get this :)
yea i had a different lens i was thinking of for characters. there's likely similarities with what you've described
Ah so one thing might be media streaming -- e.g., @Sebastian Dröge and https://gstreamer.freedesktop.org/

I added

  • GUI application
What about things like "parallel processing"?
I still think that ultimately rayon should use async
yes
that probably covers HPC?
that's what I was getting at with HPC although I'm also thinking about distributed
Ah, interesting
i.e. compute clusters

nikomatsakis said:

tmandry said:

like I said yesterday, I'd like to see a nod toward async I/O

I don't get this :)

I mean specifically disk I/O. like building a next generation database using async Rust
so databases

Loosely, I had thought of these people:

  • Existing users (the characters I see listed seem to be new users)
  • Team Lead (looks like Grace, focuses technical decision over ease-of-use)
  • Team member (can't chose a new technology, must "suffer" through the sharp edges of what Grace chose (and possibly ignored as not too important)
  • Tinkerers (probably cares more about something being annoying that being the absolute best?)
in general
feels like a blind spot
yes
added database clients, database servers
@Sean McArthur regarding existing vs new users...
I think that's too static of a distinction
I would imagine for example that Grace starts out as a new user
but we have multiple stories for her
after the service is in production, she represents an existing user
I'm not really sure what "existing user" means I guess other than that, it seems more like a phase that people go through
I was more worried that if we focus on "new user experience" too much, we could ignore the problems that people who have already gotten through that face regularly
I see. I think that again comes down to telling stories from different points
I definitely agree we want to focus both on people learning and on those further down the cycle
yeah, if we can take each character from new to experienced with the stories I think that'd be good
another "what are you building":
consumer of web services cough
how about operating systems :p

so @tmandry I added

  • High performance disk I/O

but I do wonder about "average disk I/O" :)
that's an interesting question though
e.g., would we ever want Hello, World! to be in async. I haven't made up my mind on this.

tmandry said:

how about operating systems :p

say a bit more about this?
I'm trying to decide if that's a category, or if it's just building on the other categories
re: general I/O, my feeling is it depends on the application
yeah so I'm trying to unpack that a bit
async rust in kernel code would be an interesting aspect, possibly covered by embedded
also not sure if @Daniel Egger, @James Munns, @Dario Nieuwenhuis, @Jonas Schievink [he/him] or other embedded people are around-- I sort of suspect "embedded" is too narrow?
and we could be more descriptive
well, anyway, we can spin this out and keep growing it, but it feels like we've got the list pretty well down
but to get to fuchsia more specifically, everything on the system is asynchronous message passing between various "microservices" (called components)
the main question is if there are any add'l axes worth considering, but I thin it's also something we can grow
I wonder how much overlap there is between authors of async runtimes, and authors of operating systems -- both more or less have to implement the layers that everything else is built on
I guess I'm also wondering whether it's worth considering "authors of async runtimes" as a group here -- and if so, how?
I guess I figure it can't hurt to put it on the list
this is more of a "yes, and" session in my mind :)
I'll add O/S too :)
relatedly, developer tooling that interfaces with a target device
what about things like async-compression library
i want to say like "middleware"
I was thinking that was "protocol library" but maybe that's too specific
leaf libraries (redis/hyper/rusoto) and middleware/enhancers (tower/async-compression) seem to be good boundaries?
yeah I think it sort of is, maybe it should be generalized a bit
and yeah, the OS/IPC applications may have significant overlap with others, but the constraints are quite different than e.g. a web service

• Protocol libraries (e.g., HTTP, QUIC, etc)
  • Middleware and other sorts of "wrapper" libraries (e.g., async-compression)
I guess rusoto is a distinct category
you're probably @Lucio Franco to group it in
ok, I'm fairly happy with this as a starting point, we can always expand
I feel like tower is an interesting use case in that it's kind of a framework, i.e. it defines abstractions for the application developer to code in terms of
same with actix
i had tower on my mind when I wrote middleware

Well rusoto orthognally wraps hyper (but acts like it doesn't since it abstracts it) while things like async-compression operate in line with IO though I guess if rusoto was done more "correctly" it would just be a zero io layer. So I guess it does fit in the middleware.
I imagine that something like the tower service crate probably wants to be a rust-lang crate (or in std) eventually

Lucio Franco said:

Well rusoto orthognally wraps hyper (but acts like it doesn't since it abstracts it) while things like async-compression operate in line with IO though I guess if rusoto was done more "correctly" it would just be a zero io layer. So I guess it does fit in the middleware.

maybe we'll just break it out, something like "SDKs for web services"
I would say tower is a more opinionated way and has many counter parts.

nikomatsakis said:

Lucio Franco said:

Well rusoto orthognally wraps hyper (but acts like it doesn't since it abstracts it) while things like async-compression operate in line with IO though I guess if rusoto was done more "correctly" it would just be a zero io layer. So I guess it does fit in the middleware.

maybe we'll just break it out, something like "SDKs for web services"

Yeah, and tonic is another example of something like rusoto.
I'm not saying tower itself, just that I imagine that the same way we want portability across runtimes
people are going to want to be able to develop middleware and things that are portable across web frameworks
it's next level :)

Ah I guess the big thing is that tower/rusoto (without its client)/tonic don't directly interact with the runtime except they do for timers sometimes :( Which makes it hard to abstract around runtimes.
anyways just thinking outloud :D
true confessons: I don't really know what gRPC is
but it sounds a bit more generic than a web service SDK :)
may not matter
I think we're way overdoing this by now :)
but I totally welcome people to expand the list
ultimately it seems like it'd be a pretty cool community resource
to talk about applications and what makes them different from one another
litterally http2 + lenght delimited encoding + protobuf and all tonic does is codegen :D its very simple but the key is that it just leverages http2/hyper/tower/http crates.
Actually Tonic to me is very similar to something like warp
almost identicaly except it supports clients and also servers
Is there going to be a certain balance of which characters we are going to focus on? Like I assume there are way more people writing web apps than writing an OS with async/await?
(I'm out of time; got to run -- thanks for the meeting!)
yeah, got to run too
this was fun
yeah I think ideally we brainstorm many ideas and then combine as much as possible
we didn't really get to the schedule question

tmandry said:

yeah I think ideally we brainstorm many ideas and then combine as much as possible

I thnk that a pure list is much less useful than more of a write-up
maybe we just want to add an "Applications" section
and have people write about them, with FAQs
yes, that would help with understanding what we can combine, too
so to loop back to the schedule
I am tempted to delay a bit to have time to work on this today
but I really don't want to delay much
we'll never be done

Lucio Franco said:

Is there going to be a certain balance of which characters we are going to focus on? Like I assume there are way more people writing web apps than writing an OS with async/await?

yeah I think this is more along the lines of "make common things easy, but make all applications possible"
the other thing I wanted to do today was do a next draft on tenets
everything is possible, and many things are easy

nikomatsakis said:

also not sure if Daniel Egger, James Munns, Dario Nieuwenhuis, Jonas Schievink [he/him] or other embedded people are around-- I sort of suspect "embedded" is too narrow?

Embedded is a wide field. :sweat_smile:I do have a very specific picture in mind when I hear Async in Embedded, so I think it's fine.
I do think we should get the blog post out either today or monday
That works, I have many thoughts on the database/web/server stuff so will keep an eye out :)
but I really like the idea of having devs from different application classes write up a quick explainer/FAQ
though I doubt we'll be able to find someone for every single one, so we might have to fill in a bit

tmandry said:

but I really like the idea of having devs from different application classes write up a quick explainer/FAQ

yeah I figure if we get a starter one up on the repo
we can request folks to open PRs
Would be great to have some example(s) so we are on the same page how to phrase those.
right
I was going to say -- who wants to write the first one or two :)
I nominate @tmandry
I can open a PR right quick with a page and framework for it though
and @Daniel Egger to talk about async in embedded :P
this is what you get for participating and answering me when I ping you

nikomatsakis said:

and Daniel Egger to talk about async in embedded :P

wfm
I can do that, maybe mon/tue at this point
well, I'll try and do a first draft today
gonna go hack up a quick PR with some placeholders
but would like to collect feedback from people within fuchsia
that'd be great

nikomatsakis said:

this is what you get for participating and answering me when I ping you

Yeah, I'm used to that... Also nerdsniping is a big thing in our environment. ;)
we'll have to explore a bit more about the FAQs, but I guess the most obvious is "what makes this application different from most others"
Oof, my typing is very off today...
